Research article Bimodal mesoporous AlMCM-41 supported NiMo catalysts for efficient hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene Hao Zhang Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Qing Zhang Investigation Guang-Ren Qian Supervision Conceptualization ⁎ Hong Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Yang Yue Validation Investigation School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, 99 Shangda Road, Shanghai 200444, PR China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Shanghai University 99 Shangda Road Shanghai 200444 PR China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, 99 Shangda Road, Shanghai 200444, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract In this research, a bimodal mesoporous AlMCM-41 (B-AM41) material was prepared and applied to support NiMo catalysts for the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene. Additionally, catalysts supported on smaller and larger single-pore AlMCM-41 (S-AM41 and L-AM41) were also prepared as reference catalysts. Detailed characterizations show that the proportion, stacking degree, and length of the MoS2 active phase on the different catalysts are distinct. As a result, HDS evaluation indicates that the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity with a reaction rate constant of 10.4 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1 and a turnover frequency of 7.0 × 10−4 s−1, significantly surpassing the S-AM41 and L-AM41 supported catalysts. The superior activity of the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst can be attributed to a high sulfidation degree that provides sufficient highly dispersed type Ⅱ MoS2 phases with minimal stacking and moderate slab length. Moreover, the bimodal mesoporous structure promotes the diffusion of 4,6-DMDBT and benefits its contact with active sites. Keywords Bimodal mesoporous AlMCM-41 NiMo catalysts Hydrodesulfurization Dispersed MoS2 phase Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is a critical process in the petroleum industry for removing sulfur compounds from fuels to meet environmental regulations and improve fuel quality [1,2]. Among various sulfur compounds, 4,6-dimethylbiphenylthiophene (4,6-DMDBT) is particularly difficult to remove due to its high thermal stability and resistance to traditional HDS catalysts, posing challenges to deep desulfurization [3,4]. Alumina-supported Ni(Co)Mo(W)S2 active phase is a long-standing traditional HDS catalyst. However, the strong binding between the active metal and the alumina support leads to strong metal-support interaction [5,6], which hinders the high sulfidation of the active metal and the formation of highly dispersed Type-II NiMoS with high activity. With the decline in feedstock quality, traditional catalysts are unable to meet the production of clean fuels under conventional operations [7,8]. Therefore, the development of efficient HDS catalysts is of great significance for industrial deep desulfurization activities. In the past few decades, significant efforts have been devoted to develop molecular sieve materials with high surface area and appropriate mesoporous structures to promote the distribution of the loaded active phases and enhance mass transfer, thereby improving HDS performance. The materials involved primarily include molecular sieves such as SBA-15 [9], SBA-16 [10], ZSM-5 [11], TS-1 [12], MCM-41 [13], and HMS [14], etc. Among them, MCM-41 has emerged as a focal point of research due to its excellent thermal stability and two-dimensional mesoporous structure. However, pure silica MCM-41 exhibits low acidity and poor dispersion of active metals, which is not conducive to HDS reactions. Some studies have shown that doping heteroatoms such as Al, Ti, Zr, etc. into the MCM-41 framework contributes to improving the HDS performance of the corresponding catalysts. Typically, aluminum (Al) is considered a superior doping material, as Al-doped MCM-41 can simultaneously increase Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. It has been found that Lewis acids allow hydrogenation reactions, while Brønsted acids facilitate direct desulfurization pathways and isomerization reactions in HDS reactions [15–17]. In addition, the acidity of the support can alter the electronic properties of the loaded phase, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. Therefore, the acidity of the catalyst has a significant impact on the catalytic activity and reaction selectivity. In recent years, the adjustment of pore structure has garnered significant attention due to its potential to enhance the performance of catalysts. Valencia and co-authors [18] synthesized NiMo catalysts supported on SBA-15 with different pore sizes for the HDS of dibenzothiophene, and found that catalytic activity increased with the increase of pore size within a certain range. Recently, to further enhance catalyst activity, bimodal porous materials have attracted great attention. For example, Wu et al. [19] developed a micro-mesoporous structure of ZSM-5/KIT-6, exhibiting an excellent dibenzothiophene conversion rate due to the reduction of diffusion distance. However, the addition of micro-pores not only prevents large sulfur-containing molecules from approaching the active sites in the pore center but also hinders the interior diffusion of reactants/products in the catalyst. To overcome these limitations, bimodal mesoporous (or mesoporous-macroporous) materials have been developed and have been demonstrated to contribute to the improvement of HDS performance. For example, Zhang et al. [20] prepared bimodal mesoporous ZSM-5/Al2O3 material, which demonstrated exemplary catalytic performance in the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT after loading CoMo. Besides, Palos and co-workers [21] successfully synthesized NiMoP catalysts supported on HY/Al2O3 with meso-macroporous structures, which exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability. The above-mentioned bimodal mesoporous materials need to involve another material. Recent research has indicated that the construction of bimodal pore structures within a single material is more favorable for enhancing catalytic performance. Forinstance, Yang et al. [22] prepared a meso-macroporous Ni-Mo/Al2O3 catalyst that exhibited high catalytic activity for dibenzothiophene. They believed that the integration of this bimodal pore structure within Al2O3 further enhanced the accessibility of active sites and mass transfer performance, thereby improving the catalytic performance in HDS reactions. Based on the above, the bimodal mesoporous structure has great potential for HDS performance, which inspires us to construct the bimodal mesoporous structure in the mesoporous AlMCM-41. However, this has rarely been reported in previous reports. Herein, a two-step method was used to synthesize the bimodal mesoporous AlMCM-41 material (B-AM41), which was employed as a support for the synthesis of NiMo catalysts. Moreover, smaller and larger mono-mesoporous AlMCM-41 (S-AM41 and L-AM41) were also synthesized as reference materials. Characterization indicates the proportion and microstructure of the active phases varied over different catalysts. Consequently, the catalytic activity evaluation revealed that NiMo/B-AM41 exhibited better catalytic activity than the S-AM41 and L-AM41 supported catalysts, achieving a conversion rate of 99.2 % for 4,6-DMDBT. The excellent HDS performance of NiMo/B-AM41 is related to the high proportion and high dispersion (minimum stacking and moderate slab length) of the type II MoS2 phase, as well as the good diffusion of reactants in the bimodal hexagonal mesoporous structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 99 %), AlCl3·6H2O (98 %), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99 %), aqueous ammonia (28 %), ethanol (99.5 %), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (99 %), polyethylene oxide-polypropylene oxide-polyethylene oxide triblock copolymer (P123), 4,6-dimethylbiphenylthiophene (4,6-DMDBT, 97 %), decalin (98 %), and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98 %) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. The H2S (10 vol)/H2 mixture was purchased from Shanghai Weichuang Standard Gas Co., Ltd. 2.1.2 Preparation of supports The B-AM41 was prepared with minor modifications to reference [23]. As shown in Scheme 1 , 4.58 mmol (1.67 g) of CTAB and 5 mL of ammonia solution were sequentially added to 500 mL of water, and stirred continuously to obtain a clear solution. Then, 22.5 mmol (4.68 g) of TEOS and 1.5 mmol (0.36 g) of AlCl3·6H2O were sequentially added to the above solution. The molar ratio of SiO2: Al2O3: CTAB: ammonia in the solution was 1:0.03:0.2:1.5. After filtering and washing with deionized water, a white solid (called “primary product”) was obtained. After that, the “primary product” (0.5 g) was immersed in a basic (pH ∼ 10) ethanol solution (60 mL) containing 3 g of P123. The gel was aged in an autoclave at 100 ℃ for 2 days. Finally, the product was filtered, repeatedly washed with distilled water, dried at 120 ℃ for 3 h, and calcined at 550 ℃ in the air for 6 h. Two mono-mesopore materials were also synthesized. S-AM41 was synthesized using the “primary product” as the starting material. Specifically, the above “primary product” was dried in air at 120 ℃ for 3 h, then heated to 550 ℃ at a rate of 1 ℃ min−1, and maintained for 6 h. L-AM41 was prepared following a literature [24]. 2.1.3 Preparation of catalysts The catalysts were prepared by co-impregnation method using a mixed solution containing Mo and Ni salts. Specifically, 0.24 g (0.19 mmol) of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 0.14 g (0.48 mmol) of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O were sequentially added to 30 mL of ultrapure water and stirred until completely dissolved. Then, 1 g of synthesized support was added to the above solution and stirred continuously for 6 h. After impregnation, the sample was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h and then calcined in an air atmosphere at 550 ℃ for 5 h. The target loadings of active metal oxides NiO and MoO3 are 3.0 wt% and 16.0 wt%, respectively. The catalysts are labeled as NiMo/S-AM41, NiMo/B-AM41, and NiMo/L-AM41. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements of the synthesized supports and catalysts were conducted on an XRD-6100 instrument operating at 40 kV and 30 mA using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15 mm). During measurement, the scanning ranges of small-angle XRD (SA-XRD) and wide-angle XRD (WA-XRD) were 1.5°-8° and 10°-80°, respectively. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy of supports and catalysts was carried out on the EDX-8000 instrument. The textural properties of supports and catalysts were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460. Before measurement, the sample was vacuumed at 300 ℃ for 12 h to remove impurities and subsequently backfilled with N2. Specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (SBET), the total pore volume (VTotal) was obtained by N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.98, and pore distribution was obtained from the desorption branch of the isotherms by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Raman measurement was conducted by a Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution with a spectral resolution of 2 cm−1. The laser lines at 325 nm of a He/Cd laser were applied for catalysts. The temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) experiment was measured on the Microtrac BELCat II temperature-programmed chemisorption instrument. Before measurement, 60 mg of sample was pretreated in Ar at 200 ℃ for 1 h, and then heated from 200 ℃ to 900 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃ min−1 in a 40 mL min−1 H2/Ar mixture containing 8 vol% H2. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was implemented on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha equipped with Al-Ka (hv = 1486.6 eV, 12.0 kV) X-ray radiation. Before testing, the catalyst sample was fully sulfurized in an H2S/H2 mixture containing 10 vol% H2S at 400 ℃ for 4 h. Then the fresh sulfurized catalyst was rapidly suspended in acetone and placed in a vacuum dryer to prevent its oxidation. For the XPS measurement, the acetone was removed, and the wet residual catalyst was quickly transferred to the analysis chamber to avoid oxidation as much as possible. Pyridine infrared (Py-IR) spectroscopy was carried out to determine the type and amount of acid for the supports and catalysts. The catalyst sample was sulfurized according to the same procedure described in XPS characterization. Before testing, the sample was purged with Ar gas for 3 h to remove impurities and then degassed in a vacuum chamber at 350 ℃ for 4 h. Afterwards, pyridine was saturated and absorbed by the samples. The adsorption system was degassed and evacuated at temperatures of 200 ℃ and 350 ℃, respectively, and the IR spectra were recorded in the range of 1700–1400 cm−1. To quantitatively compare the properties of MoS2 on different catalysts, a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) experiment was carried out on an FEI Talos F200S microscope. The catalyst sample to be measured was sulfurized according to the same procedure described in XPS characterization. Before testing, the wet residual catalyst was sonicated in absolute ethanol for 20 min. At least 25 micrographs of each sample were collected to analyze the slab length and stacking number of MoS2 slabs. At least 230 slabs were selected for each image to quantitatively analyze the morphological characteristics of MoS2 slabs. The average length (L av) and average stacking number (N av) of the MoS2 slabs were calculated according to the following equations [25]: (1) L ( N ) av = ∑ i = 1 n ( n i l i ) / ∑ i = 1 n n i where li is the slab length of MoS2, ni is the number of the particles with li length or N i layers, and N i is the number of layers in the particle i. The dispersion of MoS2 (f Mo) is expressed by the following equation [26]: (2) f Mo = ( Mo edge + Mo corner ) / Mo total = ∑ i = 1 t ( 6 m i - 6 ) / ∑ i = 1 t ( 3 m i 2 - 3 m i + 1 ) Where mi is the number of Mo atoms along one side of the MoS2 slab determined by its slab length (mi = L/0.64 + 0.5). The edge/corner ratio of a MoS2 slab (f e/c) was calculated by the following equation [27]: (3) f e / c = (10 L av /3.2-3)/2 2.3 HDS evaluation The HDS reactions were implemented in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (inner diameter 5 mm, length 500 mm). The catalyst was directly sulfurized in an H2S/H2 mixture containing 10 vol% H2S at 400 ℃ for 4 h. 0.3 g of sulfurized catalyst diluted with 1.5 g of silicon carbide (SiC) was uniformly mixed and loaded into the reactor. The HDS experiments were performed at a constant H2 pressure of 4 MPa, a temperature of 290 − 350℃, a weight liquid hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 4–90 h−1, an H2/oil ratio of 500, and 0.5 wt% of 4,6-DMDBT in decalin. The product was analyzed using a 9890B gas chromatography equipped with a flame photometric detector (FPD) and an RB-1 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (PerkinElmer Clarus 690). The conversion of 4,6-DMDBT was calculated by the following equation: (4) X = C in - C out C in × 100 % where Cin and Cout are the 4,6-DMDBT in feed oil and out oil, respectively. Before the experiment, the mass transfer resistance was verified using Weisz Prater criteria (CW-P) and Mears criteria (CM) [28]. The detailed results in the supporting information indicate that internal and external diffusion restrictions can be ignored. In addition, assuming that the HDS reactions of 4,6-DMDBT follow pseudo-first-order reaction kinetics. In this case, the HDS reaction rate (k HDS, mol g−1 s−1) and turnover frequency (TOF, s−1) were determined according to the following equations [11,29]: (5) k HDS = - M W ln ( 1 - X ) (6) TOF = F × X n × f Mo where M represents the feeding rate of 4, 6-DMDBT (mol s−1), W represents the catalyst mass (g), X is the conversion of 4, 6-DMDBT, n is the molar quantity of Mo atoms in the catalysts, and f Mo represents the dispersion of MoS2 slabs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of supports The SA-XRD patterns of the three synthesized materials are shown in Fig. 1 a. Three peaks were observed in all materials within the range of 2° ∼ 6°, which can be attributed to the typical Bragg reflections (100), (110), and (200) of MCM-41 material, with a typical ordered hexagonal mesostructure and long-range two-dimensional arrangement of channels [13]. The different d 100 spacing values of the three supports calculated by the Bragg equation result in different a0 values (Table 1 ), which may be related to the number of Si4+ ions isomorphically replaced by Al3+ ions. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution results of the supports are presented in Fig. 1b and c, respectively. All synthesized materials exhibited reversible N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of type IV, with H-1 hysteresis loops (Fig. 1b) [30,31], confirming the existence of the mesoporous structure of the synthesized materials. The structural properties of the supports obtained from the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm are summarized in Table 1. The SBET and pore volume of the three supports were not significantly different. As depicted in Fig. 1c, there was a significant difference in their pore distribution. The pore size distribution curves of S-AM41 and L-AM41 both presented narrow single peaks concentrated at 3.1 nm and 5.6 nm, respectively, indicating that their pore distribution is relatively uniform. In addition to the peak at 3.2 nm, a peak at 5.1 nm was observed on B-AM41 (inset of Fig. 1c), demonstrating the presence of a bimodal mesoporous structure. To further investigate the ordered mesostructure of the synthesized supports, TEM tests were conducted, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . As depicted in Fig. 2a and c, the measured intragranular pores of S-AM41 are approximately 2.9 nm, while those of L-AM41 is approximately 5.7 nm. For B-AM41, there are two types of measured intragranular pores, around 3.1 and 5.3 nm, respectively, which further suggest a bimodal mesoporous structure. Moreover, the measured intragranular pore sizes of the three materials are very close to the pore size values obtained from N2 physical adsorption. Combining the above results, it is inferred that the formation of large mesopore of B-AM41 occurs in the second stage, where P123 participates in the formation of micelles (Scheme 1). At this stage, the primary AlMCM-41 gel particles are soft and deformable. When immersed in a surfactant solution, primary particles aggregate around the micelles. The surface silanol groups exposed to the micelles link to the hydrophilic heads of the surfactants through hydrogen bonds, while the silanol groups from nearby particles condense around the micelles at higher temperatures. Under such conditions, larger mesopores are formed. 3.2 Properties of catalysts 3.2.1 Oxidized catalysts Fig. S1 shows the SA-XRD pattern of the calcined NiMo catalysts. The three diffraction peaks were preserved in the range of 2 − 6°, indicating that the long-range pore arrangement of all the supports did not change after Ni and Mo deposition. In addition, the specific surface area and pore volume of the corresponding catalysts are reduced compared with the supports (Table S1). The existence form of active metal oxides on the catalyst was analyzed using Raman spectroscopy, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 a. In the Raman spectra of all catalysts, four peaks appear at approximately 831, 902, 954, and 986 cm−1. The peak at 831 cm−1 is likely due to the Mo-O-Mo bonds in polymerized Mo oxide species (orthorhombic molybdenum trioxide) [10]. The peak at about 902 cm−1 belongs to tetrahedrally coordinated Mo species. Moreover, the strong peak at approximately 954 cm−1 should be assigned to the combination of octahedrally coordinated Mo oxide species and Mo8O26 4− species [10,33,34]. These species possess a weaker interaction with the support and is easily reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere, making it easy to form type II sulfide phases during the sulfurization process, which is conducive to the generation of active edges and the HDS reactions. The peak fitting results of Raman spectra of different catalysts are shown in Fig. S2. It can be observed that the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst has a higher ratio of peak area at 954 cm−1 than other catalysts, implying its high content of octahedrally coordinated Mo and Mo8O26 4− species. Therefore, the sulfurized NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst may have a higher type II active phase. Additionally, the peak at around 986 cm−1 can be attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration of well-dispersed MoO3 phases [35]. The reducibility of active metals on catalysts was studied by H2-TPR. The H2-TPR spectra of different NiMo oxide catalysts are presented in Fig. 3b. They possess similar contours in the range of 200 ℃ to 900 ℃ and can be divided into two areas: the low-temperature area (LTA, 200–500 ℃) and the high-temperature area (HTA, 500–900 ℃). The first peak in LTA can be attributed to the step of dispersed octahedral Mo species reducing from Mo6+ to Mo4+ (Mo6+ + 6e− → Mo4+) [36,37]. The first peak in HTA can be attributed to the reduction of Mo4+ to Mo0 (Mo4+ + 4e− → Mo0) [38]. The second peak (570–630 ℃) of the three catalysts under HTA should be designated as the reduction of the slightly aggregated bulk MoO3. Compared with NiMo/S-AM41 and NiMo/L-AM41 catalysts, the two main reduction peaks of NiMo/B-AM41 catalysts shift towards lower temperatures. Generally, the lower the reduction temperature, the weaker the MSI and the easier it is to vulcanize. It should also be noted that the hydrogen consumption of NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst corresponding to the first peak in LTA is higher than that of NiMo/S-AM41 and NiMo/L-AM41 catalysts (Table 2 ), which means that NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst has more easily reducible Mo species. Therefore, the bimodal mesoporous is beneficial for weakening the interaction strength between octahedral Mo species and supports, and further increasing their proportion. 3.2.2 Sulfurized catalysts The sulfurization degree and state of active metals (Mo and Ni) in the catalyst are crucial for the HDS reactions, therefore relevant parameters are obtained utilizing XPS spectroscopy. The XPS deconvolution results of Mo 3d and Ni 2p are presented in Figs. 4 and 5 , respectively. Table 3 summarizes the relevant XPS parameters. Fig. 4 reveals that Mo exists in the form of Mo4+(MoS2) with binding energies (BEs) of 229.0 ± 0.1 eV (3d5/2) and 232.2 ± 0.2 eV (3d3/2), Mo5+ (MoOxSy) with BEs of 232.2 ± 0.1 eV (3d5/2) and 235.3 ± 0.2 eV (3d3/2), and Mo6+ (MoO3) with BEs of 230.2 ± 0.1 eV (3d5/2) and 233.4 ± 0.1 eV (3d3/2), respectively [2,39]. Additionally, the peak at 226.0 ± 0.1 eV can be attributed to S 2 s [40]. The higher the content of Mo4+ species, the higher the sulfurization degree of Mo. The proportion of Mo4+species in Table 3 increases according to the sequence of NiMo/S-AM41 < NiMo/L-AM41 < NiMo/B-AM41, suggesting the highest proportion of MoS2 species (76 %) on NiMo/B-AM41. The deconvolution results of the Ni 2p XPS spectra for different catalysts are depicted in Fig. 5. It reveals that the spectra for each catalyst are decomposed into four peaks. The peaks at 852.4 ± 0.1 eV, 853.7 ± 0.1 eV, and 856.2 ± 0.2 eV should be attributed to NiSx, NiMoS, and Ni2+, respectively [41,42]. Additionally, the Ni 2p peak around 861.4 ± 0.2 eV is due to the shake-up of oxidized Ni2+ species [40,43]. Furthermore, the peak fitting information of Ni 2p species in Table 3 indicates that the proportion of Ni-promoted MoS2 active phase (NiMoS species) follows the order NiMo/B-AM41 (65 %) > NiMo/L-AM41 (55 %) > NiMo/S-AM41 (48 %), consistent with the Mo 3d XPS ranking. The above results suggest that NiMo/B-AM41 possesses the highest proportion of MoS2 and NiMoS phases, which will provide abundant HDS active sites. The microstructure of the MoS2 slab is an important factor determining the catalytic performance of corresponding HDS catalysts, especially in the remove of high refractory sulfides with spatial hindrance. HRTEM measurement was applied to obtain the microstructure and distribution of the MoS2 slab. Representative images of different catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 6 a–c. The stacking number and length distribution of MoS2 crystal slabs with different catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 6d–f and g, respectively. On the NiMo/S-AM41 catalyst, the stacking layers of MoS2 crystal slabs are mainly concentrated in four layers (46.3 %) (Fig. 6d). For NiMo/B-AM41, the stacking layers are mainly concentrated in three layers (accounting for 40.4 %), accompanied by a higher shoulder with a stacking layer of four, accounting for 29.7 % (Fig. 6e). However, on the NiMo/L-AM41 catalyst with larger pore sizes, four-layer stacking is predominant at 39.6 %, followed by three-layer stacking at 32.7 %. In terms of slab length (Fig. 6g), the MoS2 length on the NiMo/S-AM41 catalyst is mainly concentrated in 4–6 nm, accounting for 46.1 %, while on the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst, the slab length is concentrated in both 2–4 nm and 4–6 nm, with a similar proportion of about 31 %. In the case of NiMo/L-AM41 with larger pore sizes, the slab length of 2–4 nm dominates, accounting for 55.8 %. Therefore, the pore size has a significant impact on the stacking degree and length of MoS2 crystal slabs. For a more comprehensive comparison, the average length, average stacking, and dispersion of MoS2 slabs on different catalysts were calculated, and statistical information is listed in Table 4 . Generally speaking, lower stacking layers inhibit the production of type II NiMoS active phases, while higher stacking degrees are not conducive to the exposure of actual active sites (including corners and edges) [44]. Moreover, the appropriate length of the MoS2 slab not only facilitates the dispersion of the active phases, but also increases the accessibility of the active sites [16,45]. Table 4 reveals that the MoS2 slab on the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst presents the lowest average stacking (3.1 layers) and a moderate slab length (3.9 nm). Therefore, the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst shows the highest dispersion (f Mo, 0.33) of the MoS2 phase. In addition, Table 4 also illustrates that the edge/corner ratio (f e/c) of the MoS2 crystal slab decreases in the order of NiMo/S-AM41 > NiMo/B-AM41 > NiMo/L-AM4, indicating an increase in the number of corner sites. A good MoS2 phase dispersion is beneficial for improving the exposure of active edges, which benefits HDS activity. The superior dispersion of MoS2 slabs on the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst may indicate its high overall HDS activity. It is well-known that the acidity of the catalyst significantly affects the HDS reactions. Py-IR characterization was conducted to evaluate the acid types and content of different catalysts. The IR spectra curves and distribution of acidic sites after pyridine adsorption within the range of 1700–1400 cm−1 at 200 and 350 °C are presented in Fig. S3 and Table 5 , respectively. As reported, the band at 1596 cm−1 can be attributed to the adsorption of pyridine via hydrogen bonding, while the bands at 1446, 1582, and 1621 cm−1 are associated with the adsorption of pyridine on Lewis (L) acid sites. The bands at 1546 and 1639 cm−1 are attributed to the ring vibration of pyridine ions caused by the binding of pyridine with Bronsted (B) acid sites, and the band at 1492 cm−1 is assigned to the adsorption of pyridine related to combined B and L sites [46–48]. The acid site distribution listed in Table 5 indicates that the total acidity of each catalyst is different. The highest total acidity (200 °C) is observed on NiMo/S-AM41, with a value of 0.17 mmol/g, followed by NiMo/B-AM41 and NiMo/L-AM41 with values of 0.16 mmol/g and 0.15 mmol/g, respectively. In addition, the B/L ratio of the three catalysts decreases in the order of NiMo/B-AM41 > NiMo/S-AM41 > NiMo/L-AM41. It has been reported that B acid sites have an electronic effect on adjacent metal sulfides, which can promote the formation of coordination unsaturated sites (CUS) [49], and further facilitate the cleavage of C-S bonds in the sulfides to achieve DDS reactions. Therefore, the different acidity properties of the three catalysts will produce different effects on the activity and selectivity of the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reactions. 3.3 Catalytic behavior The conversion rates of 4,6-DMDBT at different temperatures over different catalysts are presented in Fig. 7 a. It demonstrates that the conversion of 4,6-DMDBT increases in the order of NiMo/S-AM41 < NiMo/L-AM41 < NiMo/B-AM41, which does not correspond to the order of pore size but highly corresponds to the proportion of the NiMoS active phase. The overall activation energy (Ea ) for the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reactions on the three catalysts was calculated by plotting the relationship between lnk HDS and 1/T based on the Arrhenius equation: (7) ln k H D S = lnA- Ea /RT In Eq. (7), T is the temperature (K) and R is the ideal gas constant with a value of 8.314 J K−1 mol−1. The details are depicted in Fig. 7b and Table 6 and S2. It can be observed from Table 6 that the activation energy for the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reaction on the investigated catalysts decreases in the order of NiMo/S-AM41 (106 kJ/mol) > NiMo/L-AM41 (92 kJ/mol) > NiMo/B-AM41 (87 kJ/mol), opposite to the order of the overall catalytic activity of the catalysts. These results illustrate that the overall catalytic activity of the investigated catalysts increases in the same order, suggesting that the performance of the three catalysts is closely related to the proportion of the NiMoS phases formed during the sulfurization process (Table 3). The catalytic performance of the investigated catalysts was also evaluated at different WHSVs (Fig. 7c), which further indicates the superior catalytic performance of the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst. To further compare the catalytic performance of the three catalysts, the overall reaction rate constants (k HDS) and turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated according to equations (5) and (6), respectively, as provided in Table 6. The results demonstrate that the k HDS on the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst is 10.4 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1, which is approximately 2.3 times that of the NiMo/S-AM41 catalyst. However, the k HDS value decreases to 7.2 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1 on the NiMo/L-AM41 catalyst. Regarding the TOF values of 4,6-DMDBT on the catalysts, the TOF on the NiMo/S-AM41 catalyst is only 4.2 × 10−4 s−1. On the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst, its activity increases sharply to 7.0 × 10−4 s−1, much higher than that of the NiMo/S-AM41 catalyst. However, the TOF value decreases to 5.7 × 10−4 s−1 on the NiMo/L-AM41 catalyst. The results suggest that the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reaction activity of NiMo/B-AM41 is superior to that of NiMo/S-AM41 and NiMo/L-AM41. Furthermore, the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst showed higher HDS activity for the TOF of 4,6-DMDBT as compared with the state-of-the-art catalysts reported in the literature (Table 7 ). The proportion and morphology of the active phases are the fundamental reasons for the different catalytic activities of the evaluated catalysts. Fig. 8 illustrates a 3D plot of the dependence of TOF values on the average stacking number (N av) and length (L av)of MoS2 slabs. It can be observed that the increase in TOF values depends on the reduction of N av. And the TOF does not solely depend on the reduction of L av, which is consistent with previous reports that an appropriate slab length is beneficial for the HDS reactions [16,45]. Catalysts with the minimum N av and moderate L av possess better catalytic activity. The shape of the dependence relationship in Fig. 8 is conditioned by the variation of the slab size with the support pore size. On the NiMo/S-AM41 catalyst with smaller pores, the highest N av and L av result in poor dispersion, thus showing the lowest TOF value. The NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst with a bimodal mesoporous structure has the lowest N av and moderate L av, resulting in the best dispersion (f Mo, 0.33) and thus demonstrating the highest TOF value, as shown by the visualization model (Fig. 9 ). However, on the NiMo/L-AM41 catalyst with larger pore diameters, a moderate N av and the minimum L av are observed, leading to reduced dispersion and thus a decrease in TOF value. Moreover, the bimodal hexagonal mesostructure of NiMo/B-AM41 exhibits the highest effective diffusion coefficient (Deff , see supporting information), indicating good mass transfer performance. These results indicate that the bimodal mesoporous structure is more conducive to the HDS reactions. The liquid products from the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reactions were collected to investigate the selectivity of the reaction pathway. In general, the HDS process of 4,6-DMDBT involves two reaction pathways. One of them is commonly referred to as direct desulfurization (DDS), which generates the primary product, dimethylbiphenyl (DMBP), by breaking the C-S bond of 4,6-DMDBT [52]. The other is hydrogenation (HYD), where one of the aromatic rings of 4,6-DMDBT is pre-hydrogenated, followed by the elimination of the sulfur atom. The typical products in this process are dimethyltetrahydrodibenzothiophene (DMTHDBT), dimethylhexahydrodibenzothiophene (DMHHDBT), followed by the desulfurization products dimethylbicyclohexyl (DMBCH) and dimethylcyclohexylbenzenes (DMCHB) [3,55]. Additionally, low-carbon products such as toluene and methylcyclohexane (C7) were also produced as cracking products. Apart from the products mentioned above, two other products, namely 4,4′-DMBP and isomerized MIPT (iso-MIPT), were detected, as listed in Table 8 . 4,4′-DMBP is produced after 4,6-DMDBT isomerizes to 3,7-DMDBT and undergoes direct desulfurization [56]. Table 8 clearly illustrates that the product selectivity for the three catalysts at approximately 50 % conversion is different. In all catalysts, 3,3′-DMBP and 4,4′-DMBP account for a large proportion of the products, indicating that desulfurization via C-S bond cleavage by hydrogenolysis is the preferred pathway. The proportion of iso-MIPT increases from 6 % for NiMo/L-AM41 to 17 % for NiMo/B-AM41, indicating that isomerization reactions are also an important pathway for 4,6-DMDBT. As reported, increasing B acidity can improve the electron efficiency of the active phase, thereby enhancing isomerization abilities [3,57]. Therefore, the increasing trend of isomeric products and the ranking of B acidity are well consistent. It is noteworthy that the total DDS proportion increases in the order of NiMo/S-AM41 < NiMo/B-AM41 < NiMo/L-AM41, suggesting that DDS activity is enhanced. However, this order does not coincide with the ranking of B acidity (NiMo/L-AM41 < NiMo/S-AM41 < NiMo/B-AM41), which is related to the morphology of the active phase and pore size. Proverbially, sulfur atoms of the reactant are more likely to adsorb onto hexagonal MoS2 corner sites [58,59]. The f e/c ratios (Table 4) on the three catalysts decrease in the order of NiMo/S-AM41 > NiMo/B-AM41 > NiMo/L-AM41, meaning that the corner sites increase in the opposite direction. In this case, direct adsorption of sulfur atoms from sulfur-containing molecules is promoted, followed by desulfurization via C–S bond hydrogenolysis. On the other hand, as the pore size increases, the spatial steric hindrance of the methyl group is greatly reduced, making it easier for the 4,6-DMDBT molecule to access the hexagonal MoS2 corner sites, thus the DDS reactions become easier on the NiMo/L-AM41 catalyst. Overall, the differences in reaction pathways on the three catalysts are the result of the comprehensive effects of active phase morphology, acidity, and pore size. 4 Conclusion In this study, a bimodal mesoporous B-AM41 material was prepared and used as a support to prepare NiMo catalysts for HDS of 4,6-DMDBT. At the same time, smaller single pore S-AM41 and larger single pore L-AM41 supported catalysts were also prepared as reference catalysts. The detailed characterization results reveal that the active metals are more evenly distributed on the B-AM41, ensuring its higher degree of vulcanization, and thus providing more type II active phases. In addition, the minimum stacking degree and the moderate slab length of MoS2 active phases ensure the wide dispersion of these active phases. Moreover, the bimodal mesostructured B-AM41 enhances the diffusion of 4,6-DMDBT and benefits its contact with active sites. As a result, the catalytic performance evaluation of 4, 6-DMDBT showed that the B-AM41 supported catalyst exhibited high HDS activity, with a reaction rate constant of 10.4 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1 and a turnover frequency of 7.0 s−1, which is significantly superior to the S-AM41 and L-AM41 supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this research, a bimodal mesoporous AlMCM-41 (B-AM41) material was prepared and applied to support NiMo catalysts for the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene. Additionally, catalysts supported on smaller and larger single-pore AlMCM-41 (S-AM41 and L-AM41) were also prepared as reference catalysts. Detailed characterizations show that the proportion, stacking degree, and length of the MoS2 active phase on the different catalysts are distinct. As a result, HDS evaluation indicates that the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity with a reaction rate constant of 10.4 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1 and a turnover frequency of 7.0 × 10−4 s−1, significantly surpassing the S-AM41 and L-AM41 supported catalysts. The superior activity of the NiMo/B-AM41 catalyst can be attributed to a high sulfidation degree that provides sufficient highly dispersed type Ⅱ MoS2 phases with minimal stacking and moderate slab length. Moreover, the bimodal mesoporous structure promotes the diffusion of 4,6-DMDBT and benefits its contact with active sites.
